Computer-based virtual reality simulator for phacoemulsification cataract surgery training
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 07 October 2014

Computer-based virtual reality simulator for phacoemulsification cataract surgery training

  • Chee Kiang Lam1,
  • Kenneth Sundaraj1 &
  • M. Nazri Sulaiman2 

Virtual Reality volume 18, pages281–293(2014)Cite this article

  • 548 Accesses

  • 8 Citations

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Recent research in virtual reality indicates that computer-based simulators are an effective technology to use for surgeons learning to improve their surgical skills in a controlled environment. This article presents the development of a virtual reality simulator for phacoemulsification cataract surgery training, which is the most common surgical technique currently being used to remove cataracts from the patient’s eyes. The procedure requires emulsifying the cloudy natural lens of the eye and restoring vision by implanting an artificial lens through a small incision. The four main procedures of cataract surgery, namely corneal incision, capsulorhexis, phacoemulsification, and intraocular lens implantation, are incorporated in the simulator for virtual surgical training by implementing several surgical techniques. The surgical activity that are applied on the anatomy of the human eye, such as incision, grasping, tearing, emulsification, rotation, and implantation, are simulated in the system by using different types of mesh modifications. A virtual reality surgical simulator is developed, and the main procedures of phacoemulsification cataract surgery are successfully simulated in the system. The simulation results of the training system show that the developed simulator is capable of generating a virtual surgical environment with faithful force feedback for medical residents and trainees to conduct their training lessons via the computer using a pair of force-feedback haptic devices. In addition, the successful simulation of the mesh modifications on the human eyeball with visual realism and faithful force feedback throughout the surgical operation shows that the developed simulator is able to serve as a virtual surgical platform for surgeons to train their surgical skills.

Introduction

Research on VR surgical training is becoming increasingly popular due to the rapid growth in new computing technologies, such as electronics, communications, and software development (Aggarwal et al. 2010). These improvements allow researchers to develop virtual training platforms with realistic graphics representations and interactive human–computer interfaces (Yeo et al. 2011). Many studies are being conducted to investigate the mathematical models that are suitable for the representation of the biomechanical properties of human tissues (Taylor et al. 2009; Marchesseau et al. 2010; Wittek et al. 2010). The main purpose of these studies is to reduce the visual and haptic gap between actual human tissues and virtual computer-generated tissues (Courtecuisse et al. 2010; Peterlík et al. 2010). Haptic device with force feedback is claimed to be a good controller for surgical simulators because it allows users to feel and touch the object in the virtual surgical environment rather than moving in a hollow medium (Liu et al. 2003).

Computer-based surgical training is capable of providing a controlled virtual environment for surgeons to conduct assessments and experiment on virtual human subjects, which are generated and visualised three dimensionally on a digital display unit (Pohlenz et al. 2010; Bharathan et al. 2013). In medical science, this implementation represents a new alternative for the training of inexperienced surgeons without putting live patients at risk of severe injury or blindness, such as vitreous haemorrhage that causes leakage of blood into the vitreous humour of the eye or retinal detachment that causes the retina to peel away from its underlying layer of support tissue. One of the advantages of the VR surgical simulator is that the rare events that may be encountered during actual surgical operations can be specified and customised into the training system to provide the surgeons some challenges during their practice, thus increasing their situational awareness and ability to handle such events (Haerizadeh and Frappell 2013; Yang et al. 2013).

A literature search of the various developed VR surgical simulators for phacoemulsification cataract surgery reveals that cataract surgery training is able to be virtually conducted via a computer and a pair of haptic devices (Lam et al. 2013a). Shen et al. (2008), Perez et al. (2008) and Choi et al. (2009) have implemented a corneal incision module into their simulators as part of the surgical skill training. In order to emulate an actual learning environment, Choi et al. (2009) designed, virtual rendered, and controlled a virtual keratome, which is a surgical blade that is used to create openings on the cornea during the corneal incision procedure, using a haptic device. Agus et al. (2006) and Choi et al. (2009) have introduced a progressive cutting method to represent the tearing process in the simulation of capsulorhexis, which is the procedure to create a circular opening on the anterior capsule in order to expose the cataract. On the other hand, the system developed by Webster and colleagues is capable of simulating the tear propagation, which is the resistance to the expansion of a tear, and interactive cutting (Weber et al. 2006, 2005). Planning of ripping manoeuvres, which indicates the ideal tearing or pulling path, for the rescue of an errant capulorhexis tear, which is a deviant tear that occurs on the surface of the anterior capsule made by the forceps, is also included in their simulation.

The phacoemulsification cataract surgery simulators developed by Choi et al. (2009) and Söderberg et al. (2007) are capable of representing the rotation of the nucleus during the simulation of phacoemulsification with respect to the force applied from surgical instruments, which imitates the actual environment of the trench sculpting procedure, which consists of creating a cross-shaped trench on the cataract in order to break it into four quadrants. Perez et al. (2008) are found to be the only simulator that consists of intraocular lens (IOL) implantation training, which is the procedure where an artificial IOL is used to replace the cloudy natural lens in the patient’s eyes in order to restore vision. A lens injector and hook, which are the tools that are used during the actual procedure of IOL implantation, are rendered in their system to conduct the training of IOL positioning and insertion on the capsular bag. According to the literature study, the four main procedures of the surgery, namely corneal incision, capsulorhexis, phacoemulsification, and IOL implantation, have not been completely incorporated in most of the currently available simulators yet, such as the EyeSi Surgical® and PhacoVision®. This issue can be considered a great motivation for the research and the development of an improved computer-based simulator with the incorporation of VR technology to provide a better virtual surgical environment for medical trainees to learn, practice, and assess their surgical skills in a controlled situation. The proposed simulator will be a useful tool to increase the level of proficiency of the ophthalmologists and will contribute to the introduction of virtual surgical training into the current medical programme.

This article presents the development of a VR surgical simulator for phacoemulsification cataract surgery. The developed training system focuses on the graphical simulation of the surgical technique for the four main procedures that are involved in the surgery: corneal incision, capsulorhexis, phaco-sculpting, and IOL implantation. The rest of the article is organised as follows. The system architecture of the phacoemulsification cataract surgery simulator is introduced briefly in Sect. 2. The concept and methodological approach used to implement each procedure into the simulator are addressed in Sect. 3. The result of the simulation for each procedure is illustrated in Sect. 4. Section 5 discusses the comparison of the developed simulator with other existing simulators and the conclusions of the study are presented in Sect. 6.

System architecture

The system architecture of the developed simulator consists of three main systems: a simulation system, a haptic rendering system, and a graphics rendering system (Lam et al. 2013b). A pair of SensAble Phantom Omni haptic devices is included in the system to provide the control of the virtual surgical instruments during the surgical simulation and to generate force feedback. These devices exhibit six degrees of freedom (DOFs) in position tracking and three DOFs in force feedback. The haptic rendering system is included to obtain the contact point and force from both of the styli’s movement. The position, orientation, and applied force of the virtual instruments are obtained from the haptic devices’ encoders, which are the sensors that are equipped inside the haptic device. The information of the styli is processed by the simulation system to identify the type of surgical activity, such as cutting, grasping, pulling, pushing, sculpting, and emulsifying. The simulation system processes these data for collision detection and thus computes the change in the geometric data of the eye model as a dynamic deformation. In addition, the reaction force from the touched virtual object is also computed by the simulator and fed back to the users simultaneously through the haptic devices. The graphics rendering system identifies and updates the tissue deformation and mesh modification on the surface of the virtual eye model. The changes to the eyeball will be generated as three-dimensional images and output to the users through a computer display. Figure 1 shows the developed phacoemulsification cataract surgery training simulator.

Methods

Corneal incision

Corneal incision is the first procedure performed during cataract surgery, in which a tunnel is made on the temporal limbus of the cornea to provide an access point for the other surgical instruments used in the subsequent procedures (Langerman 1994). The developed VR simulator is capable of simulating this procedure repetitively in a virtual surgical environment for training ophthalmologists to approach a predetermined position in making the correct incision.

The simulation of the corneal incision can be illustrated by modifying the surface mesh of the virtual cornea model, which is a collection of vertices, edges and facets that defines the shape of the cornea in 3D space. The human cornea in the virtual surgical environment is represented by a combination of triangular facets. The system will determine the position of the incision point between the tip of the keratome blade and the surface of the cornea when the applied force that is obtained from the sensors of the haptic device exceeds the breaking point of ocular tissue. The breaking point was manually tuned and set by an experienced ophthalmologist through repeated trials during the design of the simulator. The facet that is touched by the incision point has to be verified to simulate the mesh modification of the surface, and an opening is formed around the point to imitate the wound. The total distance between the vertices of every facet and the incision point is compared to locate the closest facet that is touched by the incision point. Figure 2 illustrates the determination of the total distance to a facet.

After the closest facet is determined, the system identifies the closest vertex, i.e. the vertex that is situated in the shortest distance from the incision point. The neighbouring vertices that are connected to the closest vertex are selected by referring to the facets of the mesh. To imitate the incision on the surface of the cornea, two new vertices are created and positioned between the incision point and the closest vertex and thus replace the closest vertex. The facets that are formed by the combination of the closest vertex with its neighbouring vertices are then rearranged to provide a tunnel on the surface. The vertices that are connected with only one of the vertices of the closest facet form new facets with the new closest vertex. In contrast, the vertex that is connected to two of the vertices of the closest facet forms new facets with another new vertex.

Figure 3 illustrates the mesh modification induced by the corneal incision. The blue points in Fig. 3c and the new vertices in Fig. 3d represent the closest vertex, the green points in Fig. 3c and d are the vertices that are connected to the closest vertex, and the yellow area in Fig. 3d is the wound created by the incision. This method is implemented in the cataract surgery simulator to imitate the corneal incision because the number of facets in the facet container remains the same before and after the modification to the surface mesh of the cornea. Therefore, the additional consumption of graphics processing power can be avoided. Figure 4 illustrates the concept of corneal incision in the proposed VR simulator.

Capsulorhexis

Capsulorhexis is well known to be the most difficult procedure in phacoemulsification cataract surgery. The outermost surface of the lens, which is named the anterior capsule, has to be removed during this procedure to expose the cataract for phacoemulsification. Forceps are used during capsulorhexis to create a flap from the capsule and to move it in a circular motion around the centre of the lens (Gimbel 1990). The developed VR simulator is capable of simulating this procedure repetitively in a virtual surgical environment for training ophthalmologists to tear a circular opening on the anterior capsule with ideal size.

The anterior capsule is the thin and soft outermost surface of the lens. Tissue deformation is implemented into the VR simulator to provide visual outcome on the simulation of the capsulorhexis procedure. A soft tissue model was used to simulate the lens of the human eye, which deforms as it interacts with the virtual surgical instrument. The mesh of the lens is modelled by a group of vertices that include various properties, such as position, velocity, and force. The geometric representation of the deformable tissues has to be analysed to acquire physical accuracy because the application of surface deformation consumes a large amount of memory and processing power. A mathematical model of the natural lens has to be built to obtain a deformation of the ocular tissues. The tissue deformation vector is dependent on the direction of the force applied with the virtual surgical instrument.

A triangular mesh of the connected vertices in the mass-spring model is used in the developed simulator. Each vertex has neighbouring vertices that link to each other to form a triangular facet. The virtual mass of each vertex has to be implemented, and distance relationships between the vertices have to be calculated. The parameters of the spring constant, which are the damping ratio and the stiffness, are embedded into the 3D mesh as the deformation characteristics (Webster et al. 2004). The total force exerted on each mass is calculated, and the position vectors are then determined to simulate the soft tissue deformation during each time step (Meier et al. 2005).

Mass-spring systems have been widely used in computer graphics applications because of their simplicity, speed, and acceptable accuracy. In mass-spring simulations, the geometry of a deformable object is represented by a 3D mesh consisting of n nodes that are interconnected through m links. Each node in the mesh represents a virtual mass and is called a mass point. The displacements of these mass points describe the deformation of the object (Choi et al. 2009). It is assumed that the springs are weightless. These springs define the distance relationships between the mass points because the deformation characteristics are embedded into the 3D mesh through spring parameters (stiffness and damping) (Webster et al. 2005). In mass-spring systems, the mass-point forces consist of the forces from the environment and the forces generated by the springs themselves. The fourth-order Runge–Kutta method, which is an iterative method in numerical analysis that generates a sequence of improved approximate solutions, was used as the ordinary differential equation for the mass-spring system in the simulator. This method is known to be one of the most powerful predictor–corrector algorithms because it exhibits high accuracy and is well behaved for a wide range of problems (Zhang et al. 2005).

The capsulorhexis procedure can be simulated by implementing the feature of grasping and tearing on the deformable surface mesh of the lens. The grasping point is identified by the haptic rendering system when the user clips the surface of the anterior capsule with the virtual forceps. The vertex that is situated closest to the grasping point is determined by comparing the distance between each vertex of the lens model and the grasping point. The pulling force from the forceps is applied on the closest vertex, and the deformation of the anterior capsule’s surface is rendered by the graphics rendering system. The links that are connected between the closest vertex and the neighbouring vertices lengthen according to the pulling force, and the effect is spread even further to other vertices that are positioned close to this particular region due to the implementation of a mass-spring system for ocular tissue deformation.

The feature of tearing is triggered when the length of the link between the two vertices exceeds the breaking point, and a new vertex is added between the two vertices to disconnect the link and separate the surface mesh into two parts. The tear progresses according to the direction of the forceps manoeuvres, and this procedure is considered complete when a round-shaped opening is created. The ideal outcome of capsulorhexis is the creation of a proper-sized circular tear on the anterior capsule. Figure 5 shows the mesh modification induced by the grasping and tearing procedures of the capsulorhexis method.

Phacoemulsification

Phacoemulsification is a surgical procedure that involves the emulsification and the removal of the crystallised lens, which is also known as a cataract. Two grooves that are perpendicular to each other across the centre of the nucleus are needed to be made during the virtual surgical training to separate the cataract into four identical quadrants, and this step is followed by the removal of each quadrant (Blaylock et al. 2006). A phaco-probe with ultrasonic vibration is virtually constructed and used throughout the simulation of this surgical procedure to break the crystalline lens into small fragments. The developed VR simulator is capable of simulating this procedure repetitively in a virtual surgical environment for training ophthalmologists to divide the cataract into four quadrants and remove it from the eye.

Phacoemulsification can be simulated in the VR simulator by implementing the feature of phaco-sculpting. The contact point is identified by the haptic rendering system when the tip of the virtual phaco-probe touches the surface of the cataract. The upper button on the Phantom Omni stylus is programmed to trigger the phaco-sculpting mechanism. A spherical region is formed in front of the tip of the virtual phaco-probe when the mechanism is activated. The facets that are situated inside the hemispherical region are removed by the simulation system to replicate the effect of phacoemulsification. To determine which facets have to be removed from the mesh, each facet of the cataract is measured by comparing the distance between its vertices and the contact point. A mild vibration sensation is generated on the stylus by the haptic rendering system to imitate the feedback of the irrigation/aspiration system from the phaco-probe during actual cataract surgery after the phaco-sculpting mechanism is activated. Figure 6 illustrates the mesh modification induced by phaco-sculpting in the phacoemulsification procedure.

The phacoemulsification procedure, which is simulated during the virtual cataract surgery training, involves the technique of nucleus rotation during virtual training on the divide and conquers nucleofractis procedure. The nucleus of the virtual crystallised lens has to be rotated 90° after the first groove across its centre is made. The nucleus is rotated counter-clockwise or clockwise according to the direction of the force that is applied on the surface of the lens by the hook. A rotation matrix around the z-axis of the three-dimensional medium is used to implement the effects of the rotational movement on the cataract. The magnitude of the vectors from the x-axis and y-axis is calculated to determine the degrees of rotation. Figure 7 illustrates the concept of nucleus rotation in the divide and conquers nucleofractis procedure.

Intraocular lens implantation

The IOL implantation is usually the last procedure performed during cataract surgery if the wound created by the corneal incision does not required any stitches. The modern IOL is mostly composed of acrylic or silicone and folded into an injector to be implanted inside the capsular bag (Ayoub 1998). The two haptics at the side of the IOL function as the suspension system to hold the position of the lens. The developed VR simulator is capable of simulating this procedure repetitively in a virtual surgical environment for training ophthalmologists to locate the ideal position in implanting the artificial lens.

The IOL implantation procedure is simulated in the virtual surgical training platform by implementing the feature of implantation. A virtual IOL injector was designed to replicate the actual tool. The coordinate of the tip of the injector is updated by the haptic rendering system throughout the operation. When the user manoeuvres the tool into the capsular bag and presses the button of the stylus, an IOL is generated in the virtual surgical environment. The position of the tip of the injector is taken as the centre point of the lens. Figure 8 shows the feature of IOL implantation.

Results

Simulation of corneal incision

The corneal incision procedure, which requires the creation of a main tunnel and a side port on the temporal limbus of the cornea such that other surgical instruments are able to be introduced to perform the subsequent operations, was included in the proposed cataract surgery simulator by implementing the feature of incision. A virtual keratome blade was designed and rendered in the surgical simulator as the tool to make the respective incisions on the surface of the cornea.

Figure 9 shows a screenshot of the cataract surgery simulator, in which the cornea and a keratome blade are generated in the virtual surgical environment for corneal incision training. As shown in Fig. 9a, the tool touches the cornea and applies force to penetrate through the surface. The system identifies the position of the point of incision and measures whether the force is sufficient to break the surface. As observed in Fig. 9b, an incision with the width of the keratome blade is made when the force exceeds the penetration threshold. The vertices surrounding the incision point are then regrouped to form new facets to make a gap on the mesh of cornea model.

The result of this mesh modification shows that the system is capable of simulating the corneal incision process without the addition of a number of new facets, which may increase the consumption of graphical processing power. In addition, the reaction force fed back to the user from the haptic device provides a sensible feeling of touching the cornea with the surgical instrument.

Simulation of capsulorhexis

The capsulorhexis procedure involves the removal of the centre part of the anterior capsule from the crystallised lens. This is achieved by the grasping and tearing of the surface, which results in deformation of the surface. The feature of dynamic surface deformation was implemented into the mesh model of the lens using mass-spring systems to simulate the mesh modification of the ocular tissue.

The surface of the lens deforms when the surgical instrument applies force on it. The vertices situated near the contact point between the surface and the tool exhibit a higher deformation compared with the other vertices because the springs and dampers of the mass-spring system, which are connected between the vertices in the mesh, reduce the magnitude of force transferred throughout the network. As observed in Fig. 10b, the surface of the lens deforms according to the direction of the force that is applied through the tool. The facets near the contact point move a greater distance from their original position. The surface of the lens deformed even further away from the original location, as shown in Fig. 10c, when the magnitude of force is increased, and the area of the deformation becomes larger because the resultant force is able to be transferred to vertices situated further from the contact point.

The simulation results show that the implementation of fourth-order Runge–Kutta method is able to support the dynamic visualisation of the surface deformation in the cataract surgery simulator by calculating the geometrical properties of all of the individual particles in each time step.

A circular opening has to be made and centred on the anterior capsule using forceps to expose the cataract for the subsequent procedure, namely phaco-sculpting. The forceps was designed and rendered in the virtual surgical environment as the tool used for the capsulorhexis procedure. To imitate the actual surgical procedure, the feature of grasping and tearing was implemented in the simulation system by modifying the mesh model of the lens.

Figure 11a and b shows that the vertex situated closest to the contact point between the forceps and the anterior capsule is grasped and pulled by the tool. The areas of the facets that are located near the grasping point are expanded proportionally to the distance moved by the tool because the position of the vertices that are connected to the grasping point is influenced by the deformation of the mass-spring system. The links between the vertices are disconnected, as illustrated in Fig. 11c and d, when the circular motion performed by the forceps extends the length of the links to the breaking point. At this point, the feature of tearing creates the visual effect of breaking the bond between the ocular tissues.

Simulation of phacoemulsification

Figure 12a shows the creation of the first groove, which goes across the centre of the nucleus and divides the cataract into two halves. The facets of the cataract, which are located around the spherical region of the tip of the phaco-probe, were removed when the phaco-sculpting mechanism was triggered by the user. The second groove, which has to be perpendicular to the first groove, is made by rotating the nucleus 90° because the feature of sculpting is performed throughout the same incision to limit the creation of a new tunnel. The simulation system rotates the nucleus based on the direction and magnitude of force applied to the surface of the cataract using the phaco-probe, as illustrated in Fig. 12b.

After the nucleus is rotated 90° as shown in Fig. 12c, the second groove is made across the centre of the nucleus to divide the cataract into four quadrants. Figure 12d demonstrates the emulsification process that was conducted in each quadrant. During this process, the simulator detects the facets that are positioned near the tip of the probe and removes these from the graphics and haptic rendering system. The cataract is removed from the capsular bag at the end of the procedure, as displayed in Fig. 12e.

Simulation of IOL implantation

The simulation system traces the position of the tip of the IOL injector after the IOL injector is selected as the tool to be used in the surgical simulator and the button on the stylus is pressed. The position of the tip of the injector is used as the centre point of the lens during the execution of the feature of implantation. This procedure was simulated and screen-captured at two different viewpoints as shown in Fig. 13.

Discussion

The developed simulator has shown its capability in simulating the four main procedures of phacoemulsification cataract surgery, which are corneal incision, capsulorhexis, phacoemulsification and IOL implantation, by using the suggested methods in Sect. 3. The developed simulator was compared with the simulators that have been developed by the other six research teams to identify the types of simulated procedures and the result of the comparison between various simulators is tabulated in Table 1. The comparison shows the developed simulator is the only simulator that is able to simulate all the four procedures, and it is followed by the simulators which are, respectively, developed by Shen et al., Barea et al., and Choi et al., their simulators only capable of simulating three out of four procedures. In addition, the remaining simulators are only able to simulate one and two out of four procedures of phacoemulsification cataract surgery.

Choi et al. is the only research team that had mentioned the graphical performance of their simulator in one of their published articles. Their simulator is able to achieve the graphical performance at the frame rates of 17, 23, and 10 frames per seconds, respectively, in the virtual surgical simulation of corneal incision, capsulorhexis, and phacoemulsification. On the other hand, the graphical performance of the developed simulator is recorded at the frame rates of frames per seconds in the simulation of the four main procedures of phacoemulsification cataract surgery as shown in Table 2. Since both simulator used Phantom Omni as their haptic interface, which provides the rate 1 kHz of haptic feedback from factory setting, this highlights the developed simulator is capable of providing smoother motions for virtual surgical training via computer because it can maintain its graphical performance at refresh rate of 30 frames per second, which is more than the standard rate of 24 frames per second.

Conclusion

This article presented the development and implementation of an immersive VR surgical simulator for phacoemulsification cataract surgery training. The results of the simulation of corneal incision, capsulorhexis, phacoemulsification, and IOL implantation show that the developed simulator is capable of generating a virtual surgical environment for medical residents and trainees to conduct their training lessons via the computer by using a pair of force-feedback haptic devices. Furthermore, the interactive human–computer interface of the training system allows the trainees to effectively learn fundamental surgical skills. The simulator will be further developed in the future through the incorporation of a stereoscopic display system with 3D glasses to create the illusion of depth and to thus enhance the visual realism of the training system. Objective-based performance parameters of each phacoemulsification cataract surgery procedure will be implemented in the simulator to obtain a performance evaluation system. This feature will allow ophthalmologists to assess their level of surgical proficiency and improve their skills using the evaluation report compiled from the training.

  25. Wittek A, Joldes G, Couton M, Warfield SK, Miller K (2010) Patient-specific non-linear finite element modelling for predicting soft organ deformation in real-time; Application to non-rigid neuroimage registration. Prog Biophys Mol Biol 103(2):292–303

    Article  Google Scholar 

  26. Yang C, Guo J, Han J, Liao X, Yuan Z (2013) Coupled tissue bleeding simulation in virtual surgery. Intell Comput Theor 7995:331–338

    Google Scholar 

  27. Yeo CT, Ungi T, Lasso A, McGraw RC, Fichtinger G (2011) The effect of augmented reality training on percutaneous needle placement in spinal facet joint injections. Biomed Eng IEEE Trans 58(7):2031–2037

    Article  Google Scholar 

  28. Zhang S, Gu L, Huang P, Xu J (2005) Real-time simulation of deformable soft tissue based on mass-spring and medial representation. Comput Vision Biomed Image Appl 3765:419–426

    Article  Google Scholar
